awd_abstract_narration: 9312570  Vander      This project will develop demonstrational, visual  programming techniques and determine in which contexts  programmers prefer them to textual programming techniques.    An interactive, two-view environment will be provided in  which users can create programs by manipulating concrete  pictorial, examples of data structures or by entering code  into a textual editor.  Users will be able to create journal-  quality pictures of data structures, such as arrays, lists,  trees, and graphs, fill in example values.  The system will  use various inferencing strategies to construct appropriate  general-purpose code.    Users will be able to move back and forth between the visual  and textual editors, using whichever representation is most  natural. By providing both a visual and a textual  representation, it should be possible to determine those  operations which a programmer views as intrinsically  textual.  Ultimately these observations should allow better  programming environments to be built that provide  alternative ways of creating programs.  ***
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations
